reviewText:
Early Access Review

Would I recommend Distance?
WOULD. I. RECOMMEND. DISTANCE?

In a word, yes.
But let me tell you why.

I should start with the fact that I've been playing Distance since the later stages of alpha. I've put almost two-hundred hours into the game and more into building the community, from starting a weekly event (Speedy Saturday!), doing weekly community track showcases (with over 600 tracks at the time of writing this, there's a lot of tracks to go through!), and doing a 24-hour charity livestream called Distathon to raise over $2,000 with the help of the amazing Distance community and the developers!

Not only are the devs some of the coolest people, but the community is boss and just keeps growing.

The game itself features tight controls, a solid learning curve, a sick soundtrack, intense level design and so much more. All wrapped up in a nice little burrito of tron-hotwheels-mashup goodness.

One of the VERY few games that's able to keep me coming back, I believe if you're at all interested in a game that's the lovechild of tron and hotwheels, you'll enjoy this.

:)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Distance is a very fun futuristic stlyed racing game which i would highly recommend.

The actual gameplay is exactly what you see in the trailers and features both single player and online multiplayer. The 'Adventure Mode' which is the campaign at the moment is quite short with only 11 maps which took me just under 2 hours to complete, but these maps were very good at introducing me too the game slowly and made the learning curve very small while still teaching me many new mechanics in each level. In addition to the Adventure mode there is Arcade Mode which allows you to replay levels over and over to get better times in both Official and Community maps.

The community maps in this game are very exciting and just as good as the official maps. Many dedicated people frequently make and upload new maps to the steam workshop which is great as it keeps the game new and fresh. All these community maps are playable Online aswell as single player.

The online mode is great, although there is usually only 2-3 servers up at a time with a maximum of 6 players you can easily set up your own through port-fowarding. With friends this game can become very competetive, even if you dont have any friends that buy this game with you the community is awesome, you meet new players everyday aswell as playing again with the ones you met the day before. Everyone is extremely supportive on those levels where you are the last to finish and everybody is spectating you but you just can't get past a bit, they say what you should try and even if you DNF you have the next map to beat them on.

Overall it is a great game with or without friends even though it is currently in early access and i cant wait to see the future additional content to be realesed with the updates to come.

TL:DR

Pros:
- Fun
- Great learning curve with the Adventure Mode guiding you through
- High mechanical skill cap
- Competetive
- 5 different game modes
- Sprint (racing)
- Speed and Style (racing but you do flips to get more points)
- Challenge (racing or short very difficult tracks)
- Stunt (do flips and get points)
- Trackmogrify (random gen levels)
- Supportive and nice community
- loads of community levels uploaded

Cons:
- Small player base leads to only 2-3 servers at a time (unless you host your own)
- Is in Early Access

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Distance is worth buying if you're looking for a racing game that involves more than driving down a basic track. It will only take you about an hour to drive through all of the tracks, but there is multiplayer locally and online, and you can retry tracks to see if you can get to the top of the leaderboards. The mechanics definitely make the game more hardcore than other racing games, but if you don't care about leaderboards, the game's difficulty goes way down if you don't continuously boost and ignore the shortcuts and other harder areas to drive through.

I enjoy Distance, because I'm a guy who loves arcade-ish racing games in general. The question whether you'd like it is depending on your taste of games. It's a racing genre that needs more explanation.
So here is my review with a comparison to the older, yet free game Nitronic Rush".

The control of the car is great and is heavily improved upon since Nitronic Rush
date: where you'd fling around carelessly by accident (though this was a lot of fun). Small turns in Distance are not as easy to make though. A controller is nice to use in case you want to aim for a nice time on a track.\n\nThe story mode
hoursPlayed: has an enjoyable exploration feeling; much like it's earlier version. Shame it's not finished yet
voteText: but it looks to be promising. Playing this with some friends by giving each other the controller or keyboard is a lot of fun too.\n\nThis all is nothing I was worried about when it came to purchasing Distance. What worried me and still slightly does is the replayablity of the game. As of now Distance
helpfulPercent: does not have this so much. Nitronic Rush was free and for me the joy was kinda out of it when I completed the storyline. You've kind-of seen it all by the time you're done with it. Distance's multiplayer aspect improves on this a lot
votesHelpful: so does the custom levels and level-editor. If all this to improve it makes the game worth the price tag of 19
votesTotal: 99 euro's; I'm not so sure.\n\nEventually after fully experiencing the Story Mode the game turns from survival exploration racing to precision racing. It's kind of the same thing as Trackmania actually. Although there's more control over your car and it's set in a whole different setting. If you're much into precision racing; I see you'll have a decent amount of replayability with this game. Yet if you're only in for the exploration
votesFunny: I think you're through the game rather quickly.\n\nGet this game if you like precision racing
commentsCount: otherwise wait for a 40% discount. 33% works if you're desperate to try it.\n\n:^)7.6*/10*grade improves as the game improves"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Distance takes the racing game genre and instead of some derpy AI cars to annoy you throws you into a world of sawblades, grinders, lasers, zero-gravity and several ways to crash horribly with only yourself to blame.

Jimp, flip, spin, fly and boost your way to victory with the thrusters and wings at your disposal on this strange car that can operate after being cut into a single wheel, or fall into the abyss below the track and crash for the millionth time.

This game is one I will be sure to play for a very long time, trying to squeeze those extra milliseconds out of the turns or shaving off several whole seconds by finding a new shortcut to try and get higher on that global leaderboard.
With several other gamemodes to keep you entertained you'll easily want to keep coming back to this title, especially with friends.

In it's current state I'd rate it as a solid: 9.5/10
It's not a 10 because of a few optimization issues here and there.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Distance is everything I hoped for an more in a racing game. This game has brought the joy of racing back to me for the first time since Burnout 2-4, and it has a lot to do with the similar philosophy of expecting player to crash (that's part of the fun!) and letting them get right back to the challenge at hand as soon as possible.

The adventure mode, even in its current limited form is a non-stop ride of thrills, stunning visuals, and creative expression through racing. The first time I opened my car's wings and took flight I sat slack-jawed for much of the rest of the level and only stopped to laugh with pure un-fettered joy.

This game wants to challenge you, but it does not demand perfection. It wants to teach you, but it won't always hold your hand either. It wants to engage your curiousity and your creativity, in an activity that is so often highly regimented and finely tuned.

The community levels (so far) make more of a return to the familiar 'hard for hardness sake' design and don't always have such well placed checkpoints, but with the mechanics present in the game and the tools available I expect to find plenty of maps like the developer's who balance out elements of free running in a car (carkour?) and the already present intense eye-bleeding gauntlet runs.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Distance is what Aperture Science would have created if they had watched Tron Legacy. This game is absolutely gorgeous! I had to buy it the moment i played it in my friends PC. The visual, the gameplay, even the credits is a masterpiece! If i had to choose the top 3 racing games i've played this decade, i'm sure Distance would have made it second or even first position.
Enough with the compliments, let's talk more about the game.
Distance is a futuristic racing game like nothing else. You are in control of a car that can boost, jump and fly (yeah, it's a transform). The game has a storyline that feels a bit artistic. It has no narrative, just you, the stages and the musics (that i have to say, it fits just perfect with the game). Since it is still Early Access, it isn't complete yet, but i can already see it developing really good!
The arcade mode seems to be really good, even better when played with a friend or in online mode. And now with custom tracks made by the community, i can't even describe how big is the potential of this game.
BUT, it has it cons (for now, it might change in the future). In current stages, there is no bots in arcade mode. I feel like this is needed in every racing game, mainly in this game! I want to play the arcade mode when my friends aren't avaliable and online mode isn't quiet what i'm looking for everytime.
The storyline NEEDS a narrative. Sometimes you feel a little lonely when traveling through the stages and the music is low. The storyline of this game shows potential and a narrative like the one in Portal games would fit just perfectly.
If i would recommend this game to everyone in this planet? OF COURSE! This game needs more attention! I would easily pay 60 bucks for this game when it gets out of early access. It really looks like a AAA game.

Plus, spin my car in the air and land it like a boss IS SO DAMN COOL! 10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a 'Nitronic Rush' player there are lots of things I like about this game, but there are also a few points which I'd like to adress (note that this is a beta).

Let's start with the good stuff:

*Amazing style & graphics
*Intense music
*Great athmosphere
*Smooth gameplay
*Lots of different areas and modes to play in (race, challenge, stunt etc).
*A multiplayer (both online and splitscreen, which Nitronic Rush didn't include, not in real time that is).
*A level editor
*Good gamepad support


And the less good things (along with thoughts):


*I have an up to date and strong computer, yet this game sometimes has major framerate issues! Especially during the multiplayer (I'm not the first one complaining).

*This game would benefit if it featured a 'drift' system. As it is now the breaks feel a bit off and stiff. I think drifting would make this game extra intense (maybe even awarding the player with points/small nitro bonuses for a good drift?)

*The engine/nitro sounds were a bit soft and dissapointing, especially in comparison with Nitronic Rush, which felt much more faster.

*In Nitronic Rush there were big spinning blades on which you could drift/slide. Why not make those without the teeth as a drifting platform in a few areas? (as an extra).



Still this game is extremely cool and well made thus far, and don't forget it's still in it's beta state!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFun, fast-paced racing game with an awesome soundtrack and a very healthy content-creating community. Good polish for an early-access game, though futher optimization would be greatly appreciated. Online community has been both friendly and helpful in my experience. Attractive art direction and a great setting. Online isn't feature-rich at the moment, but it'll get you by. The difficulty might be a little high at the beginning, especially regarding jumping onto walls and ceilings as well as gravity shifts, but once you learn how to deal with it it becomes a joy.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Distance is a fast, challenging, and beautiful racing game built by former members of Team Nitronic (Creators of Nitronic Rush).  Distance is a more polished game in every respect, with excellent music, art style, sense of speed, great multiplayer, and steam workshop integration. It is a rare game that is exactly what you see in the trailer.

The level editor deserves special praise for being the one of the most powerful and well-designed level editors I've ever used. There are others that are easier (Trackmania's block-based editor, for example) and there are a few that are more full-featured, but the Distance editor is basically all you could need. I have a few tracks on the Distance workshop and they were made completely in the editor.

There are some minor bugs and missing features (mouse support on the main menu would be great!) but they honestly don't take too much from the experience. I used to have some problems with getting network games up but that hasn't been an issue recently.

The guys at Refract are incredibly engaged with the fans (check their twitter) and have sent emails out pretty regularly since the first day of the Kickstarter; while it's generally good to be wary of titles on Early Access, Refract have already built an excellent game and you are definitely getting your money's worth at $20.

Distance is a very high-speed and reflex-intensive racing game. It's still in Early Access, but the experience (in my opinion) is already extremely satisfying. It's the kind of game you can play for 5 minutes or for hours on end. Currently, there isn't a whole lot of official content, but the amount of community maps is absurd, and most of them are amazing. When you go online, there usually aren't many (or any) hosts, yet invariably, within ~3 minutes of hosting your own server, people will quickly begin to join. I don't know why people are reluctant to host matches, but they're there, and if you host it

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Back in 2011 a small group of 11 DigiPen students created a survival racing game. But this wasn't your typical racing survival experience. Players were thrown into an aesthetically pleasing digital world where you had to avoid various amount of obstacles as you drove fast, spun, flipped, flew, through an infected computer mainframe that doubled as a city. The game was released to the masses soon after DigiPen awarded it 5 awards including Game of the Year, Best Junior Game, Best Graphics, Best Physics, and Best 3D Visual Design. It won many awards from other Indepedent Game award shows in the following year.

What originally started off as a freeware final project for school has evolved into a sucessor worthy of it's asking price. Distance is entirely built around the control scheme and physics of it's older brother so veterans will feel right at home with this installment. And, since it plays like it's predecessor, newbies won't feel overwhelmed. This is the kind of game that's easy to pick up but insanely difficult to master. So far the devs have shown a lot of promise in new design choices and the game is updated quite frequently. For example, one significant improvement is the change to cutting hazards. In Nitronic Rush, lasers and saws would pretty much destroy you in a single hit. Now, the devs have changed that so those hazards use a dynamic damage system to actually destroy the car without ruining your run. It's so absolutely crazy to be going at full speed, cut your car in two like a banana, and try to maintain control towards the next regeneration checkpoint.

At the moment the game's campaign is unfinished but that doesn't mean other elements aren't completed. The developers generously included the entire development kit within the game itself and integrated the Steam workshop. This allows anyone to create their own tracks and, as an added bonus, gives experienced game designers the ability to add unique and original content to the tracks they make allowing for endless creativity. And, thanks to an active community, endless replayability. All this and it even has multiplayer... all for a deliciously low price of $20.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Distance really is a phenomenal game. It's fast, it's flashy, it's gorgeous and it's as casual or hardcore as you like. Its main game mode, Sprint, is all about getting the best possible time to the end of a track, while dynamic obstacles are in your way, including lasers, buzz saws, etc. Community-wise, it is the follow-up to the outstanding Nitronic Rush, which you should try if you're not sure about Distance. (It's free.) Distance has a great community already, churning out several maps a week. That fixes all that I would have labeled damning about Nitronic Rush. Additional improvements are a better physics engine, updated graphics, customizable vehicle appearance, etc. Just an amazing game, and the multiplayer is very stable.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The ambiance. The concept. The visuals. The simple pleasure of driving a futuristic, bouncing, nitro-equipped flying car around.
This game is Distance, a game where your goal is to beat levels. Wether it be by speedrunning, scoring points, or simply not dying.
Distance comes with a campaign. Short, unfinished, and with (basically) no replay value.
But Distance also comes with the Steam Workshop. And a level editor. What does this mean ? It means thousands of user-created levels for you to enjoy !


1) Stay away
2) Only recommended when on sale
3) Recommended

reviewText:
Early Access Review

*WILL BE UPDATED AT FULL RELEASE*

Distance is simply one of the best games on Early Access. The sequel to Nitronic Rush is fast, intense, and a joy to play.

The graphics in this game are glorious. The tron-like style is perfect for this type of game and the amount of color on the screen is a treat for your eyes. The cars look great, with the ability to edit the car's color and glow - making each unique to the certain player when playing online. The graphics are also optimized well, making it run on lower-end machines.

Distance at it's core is a survival racing game. Throughout the levels, you can do things like jump, boost, twist and fly. The levels have a directed path, but with the ability to fly - it adds an extra element of exploration and freedom. The game as of now has a strong amount of game modes. Adventure is Distance's story mode, it's short and doesn't really have a clear story; the levels are well designed and are fun. It's more so of a tutorial the first few levels which is good for those who have no clue what they are doing. In these levels, there are ramps, lasers, twisting roads, sawblades, and other things there to kill and confuse you. It requires a solid amount of skill, the boost has the ability to overheat and flying requires boost to actually use. It's a nice balance that doesn't feel restrictive. The sense of speed is fantastic, speeding past 3 lasers then twisting, dodging a pole and then flying over the sawblades just making it towards the regeneration checkpoint is exhilarating. There are also a bunch of other game modes as well - Sprint (time trial), Speed and Style (Time + Tricks), Challenge (Mini Challenge Levels), and Stunt (Tricks); there is also a reverse tag mode that I have yet to play. The amount of game modes are fresh and give players more to play. Lastly, is the integration of Steam Workshop. The community have already made some fantastic levels, one highlight is the replica of Rainbow Road from Mario Kart. The amount of levels and the quality of those are only going to grow. It's a match made in heaven.

The audio is solid. It's sharp and clear. Where the game's sound shine though is the music. It immerses you in the game and only boosts the intense nature of the game.

The controls are extremely smooth and responsive. I personally use a gamepad. If you do choose to use a gamepad, try using the triggers for both boost and jump as things can get awkward sometimes.

With the amount of developer-made levels, gamemodes, online play, and community levels - there is tons to do already. The best part is, the game is going to keep on growing. If you live fast, survival racing games, you must get your hands on this. At $22 (CDN), it's a steal.

PROS
+Fast
+Challenging
+Plays Great
+Optimized
+Responsive Controls
+Steam Workshop
+Gamemodes
+Little Latency (Online)
+Great Music
+Colorful and Beautiful
+Friendly Community
+Accessible Level Editor

CONS
-No Story (As of yet)
-Difficulty might be tough for some
-Glitches



GRAPHICS: 9.5/10
GAMEPLAY: 9.5/10
AUDIO: 9/10
CONTROLS: 8.5/10
REPLAY VALUE: 10/10

DISTANCE: 9.3/10
Recommendation: Buy it at full price.
One Word Description: Exhilarating""

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Absolutely fantastic. I loved Nitronic Rush and Team Nitronic (now Refract Studios) have definitely lived up to, and gone way past the fun and excitement of it with Distance. I've been in since the beta, and so far I've loved every bit of it.

While this game is in early access, I highly recommend it even if the game never updates again (which it will by the way, Refract are cool guys)

First, the level editor: Steam Workshop support and a built in level editor is a game changer for any game, and this one especially. The editors advanced features reminds me of such things as Autodesk Maya, but can be simplified down to the Portal 2 in-game map creator. Tracks in the editor snap together and can be automatically resized. They act like splines and the track automatically is generated along them, so you do not have to worry about that at all. Everything is very easy yet advanced at the same time which will make some really brilliant levels (and has already infact).

Multiplayer: This was the most requested feature from Nitronic Rush, and they've implemented it right down to the core of the game. It is done extremely well and I couldn't ask for anything more (well, maybe auto downloading of workshop levels to clients who dont have). It's really fun with mates or strangers on any of the modes: sprint, speed and style, challenge and reverse tag (shame they removed the football gamemode though).

Atmosphere: The atmosphere of the game is clear from the start and I think it works really well. There's less of the really bright colours from Nitronic and the announcer is gone (for now at least). The world is dark and gloomy but mixed with flashing lights and exciting music makes for an interesting yet enjoyable experience. The soundtrack itself is incredible, Torcht and the team really have outdone themselves this time, it's much better than Nitronic Rush's music (and for the record, I loved Nitronic Rush's music).

There are only a few things that I think should be worked. The first is optional realtime portals, since right now they work like a static 360* image wrapped around it - but don't get me wrong they look great and aren't noticeable at high speeds, of course this should be off by default and as an advanced graphics option like realtime reflections since they would require a beefy GPU. Another thing would be mod support for custom gamemode types. My biggest issue currently is no mouse support at all, not even for menus - but I'm sure it's planned (we are in Early Access right now, after all), but these are more like feature requests than actual issues - and I'm certain Refract has more up their sleeve for us, so we'll see.

Conclusion: Get this game if you love any of these:
A. Arcade racers
B. Splitscreen games
C. Sci-Fi games
D. Racers
E. Playing tag with your friends
F. Games with an amazing soundtrack
G. Calm driving
H. Exciting driving
I. Polished games
J. Multiplayer racing with friends
K. Multiplayer racing with not friends
L. Nitronic Rush
M. Ex-DigiPen students
N. Refract Studios

Okay I'll stop now, but seriously, get this game - you will not regret it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My Let's Play - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oUKOjyZNUZk

Quick Impressions: Initially the game feels kind of slow even when you have that blur-thing happening. But the first few stages are tutorials getting you accustomed to the game. Even though the game never actually gets any faster, the obstacles thrown in front of you creates a very real feeling of speed. Looking back at my LP, it does seem slow, but when I was playing, it was hectic.

There is a nice magnetic grip to the car. It's not way overpowered, it's tuned very nicely and helps with all of the crazy go-nuts car flipping to perpendicular roadways. I've already seen some speed runs and I'm excited to see what comes of it.

There are already UGC for the levels!  http://steamcommunity.com/app/233610/workshop/ Which is NUTS!  Really cool that there is so much UGC on day one when the game launches.  Easily has to be some kind of record. I toyed around with the level editor at the end of my LP and I have no idea what I'm doing, but it seems fairly simple after you get the hotkeys situated in your head.

Lastly, I want to mention that there is a very real kernel of a story present in Distance.  Which is kind of odd, because you usually don't expect stories in racing games.  But something is definitely up.

All told this game is precision racing.

Excellent job from the Nitronic Rush guys!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Distance is quite easily the best Early Access game I have played in the last two years.
There is one simple reason behind this: IT WORKS!

TLDR OR SEE MY VIDEO BELOW : Distance is a fast paced time trial racer, it has a few different modes available and is opened up to Single player, multiplayer and split screen LAN multiplayer.

There are plenty of unique and interesting official maps to keep you busy, but if you set the best times on these there is the extensive community workshop with over 200+ tracks (from date of writing) available to download separately (or all at once).

Compete against friends or the global community to try and dominate the leaderboards.

------ FULL REVIEW ------

Adventure Mode:
The game sports an adventure mode where you race your car through the official maps in as quick a time as possible while avoiding all the crazy lasers, buzz saws and twisting and winding roads while preventing your car from overheating by quickly getting through the next checkpoint.

Although there isn't a story per se the tracks are highly immersive and draw you into what can only be classified as a dystopian city scape. Throughout the adventure you seem to move from a potentially busy vibrant city into a dark lost society. If you put your imagination to it I am sure you can come up with some interesting scenarios as to what happened to this world!

Arcade:
Arcade mode is where it really gets interesting. There are a few modes to choose from:

Sprint: Basically get to the end of the track as quickly as possible to get your name on the global scoreboards. Go through checkpoints to prevent the car from overheating. Reset if you screw up too badly and push yourself to the limit to gain the fastest time possible! (this mode counts towards global leaderboards).

Stunt: Try to do as many flips, flights and wall rides as possible within the time limit to gain the greatest score. This is played in an arena mode with plenty of ramps and heights to get the maximum amount of flips in before that inevitable landing, just be sure to land upright or the subsequent landing may be more of an explosion!

Reverse Tag: There is an orb which must be collected. Each player will compete to steal the orb from the other player. Whoever can keep the orb for the longest time will win. This is played in an arena style map which has plenty of cheeky little areas to try and trip your competitors up.


Workshop:
From the date of writing there are over 200 community created tracks to try out. There are different tracks designed for each individual mode. Each track varies in length and difficulty with some sprints taking less than a minute, to first time tries clocking in at over 10 minutes.

One problem with the workshop currently is everyone must have downloaded the community maps themselves, they don't just download from the host. There is however a quick solution to this on the workshop with a subscribe to all mods" tool which allows you to instantly subscribe to all the tracks available.

Track Editor:
The game ships with its own in game track editor which provides all the tools you need to create some really exciting / wacky tracks which you can then upload to the Steam workshop and let others race and rate. There is massive room for some truly exciting and unique track experiences.

Leaderboards:
The leaderboards are what help to make this game what it is. You can see times set by the top 1000 in the global community but also filter down to personal best times and friends.
If like me you want to be at the top of your friends leaderboards you should definitely give this game a try!

Controller:
The front of Steam says the game has partial controller support although while using my Xbox controller it seemed to work 100% fine
date: I was able to re-bind keys however I liked
recommended: vibration function works no problems.\n\nIf you prefer to use the keyboard then this is fine too
hoursPlayed:
again it has 100% re-bind capabilities.

---------  CONCLUSION ---------

As mentioned at the start this is the best Early Access I have played in a long time. It works flawlessly without any crashes and very few if any bugs. One issue I have noticed is when watching another person finish a race it can get stuck playing the same loop
voteText:
however this isn't game breaking and when they finish / the timer runs out the game will continue as usual.

One small problem with the community maps is every person wanting to race online must have individually downloaded the maps. They don't download from the host. There is however a quick solution to this on the workshop with a "subscribe to all mods" tool which allows you to instantly subscribe to all the tracks available.

The game is still in beta and already I would say 8.5/10 I can't give it more because the adventure mode is not yet finished and the issues with online downloading of maps. But it is well on its way to becoming a fantastic game which could give hours of fun and frustration!


https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Uxq5m4A3hVk"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Like many, I had played Nitronic Rush, a game developed by the creators of Distance as a college project. And, like many, I fell in love with the sense of speed and control, as well as the impressive attention to quality these unpaid students had shown. If you are not sure about purchasing Distance, I urge you to try Nitronic Rush first. Now on to the review, which will be in simple slices from this point on:

Gameplay:
+Great sense of speed
+Wow factor very high
+Ability to be stylish
+Extremely hectic but fun and skill based multiplayer
-Occasional Gravity quips, but mostly as solid as nitronic rush

Graphics:
+Stunning enviornments
+Great in motion or a still screenshot
+Stylized world portrays the mood of the adventure mode well. Speaking of which...

Story:
+A visual adventure with great portrayal  of mood
+Still in beta, so improvements and overall increase in narrative are likely
+Music conveys most of the message

Music:
+I love it
+You want more explanation? Okay
+Electronica, progressive house, and dubstep fused together.
+Sound good?
+You bet

Lasting appeal:
+Workshop support for hundreds of levels
+Still in beta, expect more content!
-As of now, lacking enough to keep you busy for more than a couple days. Will improve with time most likely

Overall, team Nitronic (Now known as Refract Studios) is raising the standard for the racing genre.
Much like Sonic the Hedgehog gave the platformer genre a faster, fresher experience to the platformer genre, Distance is the new way to experience the high speed thrills of a racing game.
The Distance Beta gets a whopping
9/10 for Pre Release
And a predicted
10/10 GoTY for 2015 racing enthusiasts.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Distance is an Early Access game that is really, well, going the distance. This review was written as of 11/12/14. the game may have changed since then. As a spiritual successor to Nitronic Rush, one of my favourite racing/driving games, I imagine it will be great when it's finished. Heck, it's great right now.

The story isn't done yet, but some of the elements I've seen in its current state are very promising.

The level design in this is pretty good so far, but I feel most of the levels are tutorial-level of difficulty. It would be good to see the next levels added have a higher difficulty.

I've tested this with an xbox controller, and keyboard/mouse. Both seem to do the job well, but I do hope they add mouse support for menus sometime soon.

The graphics in this game look pretty amazing in their current state.

The soundtrack in this game is great, and if it is going to be in any way similar to nitronic Rush, it can only get better.

This game supports the workshop, so once more people good with game design get on board  in the community you can be sure there won't be a shortage of levels to play.

While this is an early access game, I do feel that the developers have proven themselves to be very competent and not just in it for a money grab. They dd private betas beforehand, and have already developed Nitronic Rush. I'm looking forward to the final product.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

From the creators of Nitronic Rush comes a spiritual successor Distance and so I will be using Nitronic Rush as a reference point quite a bit. I saw this game a while back when the Kickstarter was first started and I was hyped, however after a long while I lost track of it and forgot it altogether, imagine my surprise when a week ago I saw it on Steam, I immediately got hyped again and man I got to say I'm not disappointed. While it's still beta and it shows (the occasional physics glitch out or random death) I've really enjoyed the first two hours I've spent playing through the campaign.

First starting out I got immediately reminded of Nitronic Rush mostly because of the visuals are very similar however visuals aside this one defiantly is worth the cash, the soundtrack features some of the best electronica I've heard in a good while and I do hope they sell it on steam sometime soon, however while music helps make a good game better the gameplay is the ultimate decider of worth and as I said previously this is worth every penny. The gameplay though similar to Nitronic Rush is much quicker and a lot more precise and I felt a lot more in control of the car however I would highly recommend playing this with an Xbox controller or a gamepad of your choice as it will make the button presses and general control a lot easier. Finally the visuals, this game looks stunning and it's pretty much like a racing game out of Tron, the heavy use of neon with lines going down the car, track and objects gives it a pretty amazing atmosphere all while the background pulses alongside the beat giving a bit more character to the world around you.

Now, all that said I've got my problems with the game. While the driving is more precise when the car goes airborne being limited to just roll and pitch makes it just as frustrating as Nitronic Rush was and I can't help but feel the game would be just that little bit more epic with the ability to save yourself without having to fly out of a potential death and break the flow of speed. Finally I miss the old engine sound from Nitronic Rush, the car itself is missing the punch of sound the rest of the game so gloriously has and though it looks cool it's too quiet. Those two problems aside I adore this game already and I can't wait to see what's added later on, buy it if you have the cash because it's already worth it.

Fox out.

I crashed a lot in the beginning. I still crash even now and I've figured out most of the controls. The game is beautiful and the concept is awesome. It can be a bit daunting because the gameplay is centered around reflex in some areas but once you get into the zone and master driving it gets easier. The first person view is even crazier than the third person and personally I find it easier to control my car, from the first person view, even though having spacial awareness from this view is a bit difficult. All in all it's a awesome game. The music gets you pumped once it gets going. I feel like this game is a hell child born from a threesome Rocket League(with it's car jumping mechanics and boosts), Burnout(because it's the only game I can recall that's environment could really bone you over) and Tron.

9/10 Would crash into lasers again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note, here's a link to my video review if you prefer that medium:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eXzgsYSO8pA

Distance
Platform - PC
MSRP: $19.99

Welcome to Lair Gaming's review of Distance" for PC.

Distance is an F-Zero-y TRON-esque trip into pure chaos. The current build of the game under review (beta 4139)
date: though only in Early Access on Steam - does contain PLENTY of content to keep gamers busy. The beta version of Distance houses a pretty barebones story mode called "Adventure." It definitely IS an adventure
recommended: and there is some story to soak up here - though not a whole lot. The beginning narrative introduces us to the idea of the protagonist - which is some kind of sentient platform-mobile that looks like a car. I say looks like a car: because you'll find out over the course of the "adventure" that you have a pretty substantial range of mobility options at your disposal. As with any platformer packing some advanced mechanics
hoursPlayed: Distance starts off by treating you like a toddler. You'll have an accelerate button and be able to steer... and that's about it. But the savvy driver is soon abundantly rewarded with wave after wave of new obstacles and mechanics with which to bypass them. You'll learn how to boost right away in order to get over certain sized gaps that you wouldn't normally be able to traverse. You'll then find out that your sentient platform-mobile can sprout some wings from either side and leisurely fly in any direction. This adds a HUMONGOUS amount of range to the options you have in conquering some of the tougher challenges
voteText: although I was both disappointed and understanding when I found out that flight would occasionally be deactivated in order not to break certain difficulty barriers in Adventure mode. Additionally
helpfulPercent: boost and flight work off of the same meter
votesHelpful: and allowing this meter to fill causes you to hear an "Overheat" alarm. Overheating too long causes an explosion and a reset from the previous checkpoint. Luckily
votesTotal: however
votesFunny: checkpoints are very liberally placed throughout each map in Adventure mode.\nWithout spoiling any details of the very barebones "story"
commentsCount: which is really more of a setting than anything
column16: I would like to say that there is an underlying horror vibe present in this dystopian neon wasteland - but it's cool
column17: and doesn't feel too heavy-handed or like any conceits were made in order for it to make it into the game.\nAt the abrupt end of the included 10 or so levels of the "remember
column18: it's beta" story mode
column19: you'll find that you feel prepared to march straight into some of the other gameplay modes Distance has to offer.\n\nJust in the beta version of the game
column20: there is a huge amount of replay value already present. Distance offers a pretty well thought-out
column21: though basically what you'd expect multiplayer mode that allows groups of (currently) up to 6 players to go all Sonic the Hedgehog in maps
column22: either: created by the developers
column23: created by the community using the in-game level editor
column24: or generated by inputting "seeds" into the "trackmogrification" tool: which randomly generates levels based on strings of letters. Each of these categories offer immense replayability and are sure to keep anyone coming back again and again since the game provides such a high-level of "Wow
column25: that was so cool" moments.\nMultiplayer is purely racing. There are several modes
column28: and a sprint mode. Tag mode consists of players trying to be "it" as long as possible
column29: challenge mode consists of trying to clear tons of obstacles with no checkpoints turned on
column30: and sprint mode is just good old classic "race-to-the-finish." Each of these modes is pretty spectacular
column31: though the game misses out on achieving near-Mario Kart levels of competitive frustration since there is no collision detection between vehicles. You can see everyone else alongside you on the courses - you can even see when they SPLAT right into a barrier that popped up out of the ground while they confidently sped past at 500 miles per hour
column32: but you can't bump into them at all. It's the equivalent of playing with a bunch of ghosts. That small complaint aside
column33: the multiplayer is still very engaging - and the inclusion of text chat between participants allows for some nice banter in between matches. One glaring omission
column35: is that there is no option when creating a multiplayer lobby on or offline to disable the platform-mobile's "plane" function. [EDIT: There is an option to disable flight
column36: but it must be selected at the time of level creation rather than by the server host!] This created a situation for me where a room full of people called me a "track-skipper" because I flew from one tricky portion of the map to another (the equivalent of using a mushroom in Mario Kart to speed through rough terrain for a shortcut). Sure
column37: this is probably common sense for most people
column38: but I used the tools at my disposal
column40: and then found that this was looked down on. For good reason too. In some cases
column41: because of the layout of a track - an opponent could finish a race in 30 seconds while the rest of us trudged on for a full 2 minutes
column42: simply because he found an opening to "skip-track" to the exit. [EDIT 2: I have been assured by members of the Distance online community that "track-skipping" is very much a welcome part of the multiplayer experience as I originally hoped.] This
column44: was a very small hassle - and the community seemed to be understandingly aware that the omission of an option to turn off flight in these multiplayer lobbies is an oversight simply not implemented in the beta phase of Distance.\nAlso
column45: worthy of mention is that aside from the online multiplayer aspect
column46: there is also the "highly coveted among PC gamers" option to play in splitscreen offline.\n\nAfter you've taken the community-created tracks for a spin
column47: you may feel compelled to try your own hand at creating an amazing course filled with danger and explosions - and
column49: Distance includes a vast level editor - simple enough to get started in without much training
column50: and advanced enough that you could basically create your own standalone story with the tools at your disposal. If you thought with the advent of Super Mario Maker that maybe an F-Zero Maker was around the corner - I hate to burst your bubble; but Distance may be the closest you ever come to realizing that dream.\n\nLastly
column51: this experience is a visual delight and both audio and video build off of one another. The buildings pulsate in vibrant color to the resounding beats of the techno soundtrack. The environment moves in a showcase of sublime aural rhythm. I did notice that the boost sound coming from the platform-mobile was a little loud and kind of whiny when it hits top speed. Textures are clean throughout and obstacles on the track ahead of you are easy to see - even when they're flying at you in what seems to be an instant. There were a couple of times I felt a little turned around
column52: but with clear visual cues - I found myself back on the right track quickly. As for optimization
column53: I tested the game on my desktop with an nVidia 980TI and i7 2600k @ 1440p/maximum graphics settings and easily maintained 60fps throughout my time playing. I also tested the game at 1080p with my laptop packing an nVidia 860M and had 0 drops below 60 FPS - even when the screen erupted in a magnificent neon explosion in front of my eyes.\n\nDistance is one of the most purely fun games I've ever played. It can be very easy; it can be blistering difficult - but the undoubtedly adrenaline-filled excitement is sure to impress most. At a suggested price of $19.99
column54: Distance is totally worth its cost right now: In Early Access. To sweeten the deal
column55:
it routinely goes on sale on Steam.

column56: I give Distance on PC: an 83/100."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I haven't taken the time to review that many games in the past, however, this game was too good to pass up giving attention.

Its been awhile since arcade racers were in their prime. People are lost to the unrealistic stupid fun genre that is arcade racers, Distance by Refract Studios didn't only remind me of that same rediculous fun I used to have in arcades, but grew on it in so many wonderful ways.

in 2011 the small indie studio released Nitronic Rush, a fun experiment using a physics engine built entirely by them in C++, and it was awesome. I got my friends to download it and they all loved it, it was such a refresher from the generic races that have been coming out in years past, the ammount of insanity involved is something I hadn't dealt with in a long time.

Then came Distance, made by the same studio under the name Refract, and it gave me that same rush as the first game. The game has cars going at a rediculous speed, set in a world similar to that of Tron, with flying cars, stunts, an amazing multiplayer and one of the most challenging but entertaining single player's i've been offered in a long time.

If you're on the edge about this game, just know you wont be dissapointed, Distance is one of the most refreshing experiences i've had in a long time, and im confident Refract Studios can only make it better.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Anyone who's played the free game titled Nitronic Rush will feel right at home with Distance.  In fact, Distance is being developed as the spiritual successor (sequal) to Nitronic Rush.  And what a fantastic sequal it is.  Here are my opinions on the game as a Kickstarter backer (beta).

Pros:
-Superb graphics/environment.  The theme of the levels is fantastic (almost Tron-esque), and the music goes with the environment very well.  Light will pulse along with the music, and the overfall feeling is just fabulous.
-Excellent handling.  The cars handle beautifully, and really are easy to drive but hard to master.  Mechanics such as boosting (which has a heating system a la Motorstorm), jumping, and flying are all implemented very well.  The levels often utilize these too, creating for a unique driving expirience.
-Challenge.  Distance is fun for just your average racer, but it has a suprising depth for speedrunners.
-Level editor.  Have not used this much personally, but you can see by other people's fantastic creations that it works well.

Cons:
-Content.  The game's in beta, so I can't be too harsh here.  However, at the time of writing this you can complete the story in an hour or so.
-Level editor.  While very robust, it's not particularly easy to use.  Tutorials can be found on Youtube; they help.

If you enjoy racing games, challenging games, or speedrunning games I strongly recommend picking this up.  I have been anxiously awaiting this game since it was announced and it's been anything but dissapointing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ever since I was little, I was a huge fan of the Burnout racing game series. I played those games a lot over the course of a few years. Those games, however, made me create a standard for all racing games. If I felt a certain racing game did not meet that standard, I wouldn't buy it. In fact, In the past 7 years, I have only bought and played 2 other racing games besides Burnout. One of those, I didn't like, the other one is decent.

When I saw this game, I was intriqued. It looked unique, but I still went by my standard. I decided that 10 dollars (on sale) was a fair price and purchased it. When I started playing, I realized this game did not meet any of the standards I had set. That was because this game was truly unique. It's nothing I have experienced before. I've only played this game for a few hours so far, and haven't even scratched the surface of what you can do in this game.

The graphics in this game are stunning and it is well optimized as well. I can run everything on ultra and get 50+ fps. Even though it says Early Access, I have not encountered any bugs. It's labeled Early Access mostly because they have more content to add. If you enjoy using a controller like myself, they have good controller support as well. It has a level editor, allowing you to make custom levels and then share them on the Steam Workshop. It has nearly unlimited levels, just type in a phrase, and it will generate a random level. It has multiplayer, allowing you to play with others on any map you want. It also has a singleplayer and split-screen mode. And to top it all off, it's only 20 bucks (not on sale), which makes it even better.

To be honest, I can't really think of any bad things to say about this game. If I encounter anything, I will update this review.

In conclusion, this game is a unique racing experience unlike anything I've played before. There are so many good things about this game, and the developers are continuing to add more content. I highly recommend this game to support it as it develops.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Distance
tl;dr: A good racing game, a bit short

The full review: Distance is a futuristic survival racing game, in which you try to race to the end of each level without being obliterated by the ever so many threats. All in all, I believe the developers did quite a good job at delivering.

However, it still feels a little too focussed on racing and not enough on survival, which I would like to have seen more.

As for Early Access: The Adventure Mode is indeed a little on the short side (about 1 hour of playtime), but it was definitely fun and quite mysterious - as the game gives you very little narrative. Who are you? Why are you racing? What is the corruption?

In general, if you like racing games like TrackMania, you will likely enjoy playing this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of this review, i have put 21 hours into the game, and plan on putting many, many more on it. It reminds me alot of Trackmania, with fast-paced racing involving a time trial system.

Pros; Beautiful, Runs well on my 8gb of ram and radeon 6950, Music is really good. Physics add a fun element to multiplayer, The color pallete is gorgeous (reminds me so much of tron), Multiplayer has a variety of modes for your enjoyment, Steam Workshop maps :D, level editor, Car customization (colors, lights), ect.

Cons: Campaign is unfinished (however, they spent most of their time improving the gameplay). Flight control with a controller is somewhat hard to get the hang of (keyboard controls are great). To be honest there isn't much else i can complain about.

It's an extremely well made game, and I personally have not encountered any bugs or errors.
I would rate 9/10, Distance overall is better than most fully released games,

reviewText:
Early Access Review

***OPEN BETA REVIEW***

A fantatically designed game. The graphics are absolutely beautiful, and all the neon cityscapes that the game generates are honestly eye-boggling. The driving controls feel very smooth and easy to learn - the tough part is mastering it and beign able to maneuver the vehicle through some ridiculously hectic and action-packed tracks. Soundtrack is quite good, actually, very fitting, and all the lights actually pulse to the music with a certain setting turned on. You can even give the game a directory, and it will play any MP3 music files you have there instead of the EDM/dubstep norm. Very creative and awesome special effects and innovative ideas I've never seen brought into the racing videogame world until now, including a gamemode that randomly generates a track and environment based on a random phrase that you input. This product is very well-polished, ESPECIALLY for a beta. All it's really missing is content. I got this game on sale, but I am almost positive that it will be well-worth the $20-asking price on its full release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The futuristic racing game scene is dead as can be and me being an old fan of the genre (who loved titles like Wipeout and Extreme-G), my hopes were high for this one.  This is the only early access game I've ever purchased and in spite of that, it still manages to deliver an amazing experience.  I have no idea what the story is behind the game and if you're like me then you'd rather not know simply because the sci-fi wasteland environment the game provides is so immersive that so you'll end up creating your own story in your head.  The electronic soundtrack is exactly what you'd expect: gritty, pounding tech-house that totally puts you in the game.  As for the controls, I played with an XBox gamepad and it worked perfectly with that.
Complaints?  When you shift to drive on the ceiling, it can some times be rather 50/50 on whether or not it works.  Suggestions?  Well, assuming multiplayer is in the works, and the fact that there's already a booming custom map community, I would say let me customize my ride!
But enough of all that, the game is damn good.  So turn the lights out, the music up and get ready for one hell of a ride!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is very interesting, none the less. Even if your taste is not in racing games, it is a good pass time if you're overwhelmed from playing that Multiplayer game you typically play when you wake up in the morning. God knows when I am annoyed after playing Rust or Counter Strike: Global Offensive that it's these games I like to turn to. Overall, Distance has very many wonderful mechanisms to it. Gravity being a very affected party of this game; you need to understand how the physics of this game works if you want to play it properly. Once you get the hang of everything, however, you start to receive a lot of enjoyment out of playing the maps that are preset in the game, and even custom ones made by the community. Not only does Distance have wonderful mechanics to it, but it also has a nice developmental structure to it, and what I mean by that is it includes its own level editor, and you can make maps, such as a Rainbow Road and a Mario Kart map I've already took the liberty of playing on. I can say that this game is very enjoyable as a I have spare time and I'm not doing too much
date:
type of game. Almost like listening to music or watching Netflix while you're idling in your game server trying to get rid of that TF2 item you don't like.

The only problem I have with this game is the Multiplayer. You have to set up your own server and typically invite people to your game, because there are not a lot of random public servers to play on. They are all typically private for friends or a group of people. If they had a matchmaking feature like Left 4 Dead 2 does, then that would make Multiplayer a bit more appealing in my eyes.

Overall, I do enjoy this game, and hope that it's carried out in development further than what it is now.
Wonderful potential here, just don't end up like a lot of other Early Access games that are, very unfortunately, In early access" for two and a half years and never actually goes anywhere often. Yes

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Anyone who's played the free game titled Nitronic Rush will feel right at home with Distance.  In fact, Distance is being developed as the spiritual successor (sequal) to Nitronic Rush.  And what a fantastic sequal it is.  Here are my opinions on the game as a Kickstarter backer (beta).

Pros:
-Superb graphics/environment.  The theme of the levels is fantastic (almost Tron-esque), and the music goes with the environment very well.  Light will pulse along with the music, and the overfall feeling is just fabulous.
-Excellent handling.  The cars handle beautifully, and really are easy to drive but hard to master.  Mechanics such as boosting (which has a heating system a la Motorstorm), jumping, and flying are all implemented very well.  The levels often utilize these too, creating for a unique driving expirience.
-Challenge.  Distance is fun for just your average racer, but it has a suprising depth for speedrunners.
-Level editor.  Have not used this much personally, but you can see by other people's fantastic creations that it works well.

Cons:
-Content.  The game's in beta, so I can't be too harsh here.  However, at the time of writing this you can complete the story in an hour or so.
-Level editor.  While very robust, it's not particularly easy to use.  Tutorials can be found on Youtube; they help.

If you enjoy racing games, challenging games, or speedrunning games I strongly recommend picking this up.  I have been anxiously awaiting this game since it was announced and it's been anything but dissapointing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Distance is a really fun game and has you dodging and diving between objects to reach your final goel. the adventure mode has a great experiance that will push you and challenge you to start with, once you have mastered that, sadly there is not musch else to challenge you besides the workshop. This does not mean there is no more content because oh boy is there more content. there are random geniration maps so that is infinate fun and also challenge mode and user maps, so yeah there is a lot.

BUT the game really leaves me craving more speed and more split secound decisions. i really feel that they should make the tracks a tiny bit wider and add more speed and faster handeling later on in the game. i love the game and i love the small challenges it offeres but at the moment after playing it for a little while i feel i have mastered it and i just really want more speed and variation.

TLDR
Game is fun with a lot of content
fun to get good at, can bore when mastered
needs more speed with better handeling (only add better handeling if more speed is added)
limited variation
short tracks

Im going to give this game a thumbs up, because i really enjoy it and its great fun to play, i just feel that it has the possibility to be a great deal better if it was made harder with longer tracks and more speed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the best racing game ever. Period. Nothing else even comes close.

There is a ton of community content, and more being created constantly, meaning that there is a basically unlimited number of levels to play. The game's community is super awesome, from Speedy Saturdays (a group multiplayer event that happens every Saturday), to the forums, to the subreddit. The workshop has tons of levels for all the game modes. The game has leaderboards, and people try to get the highest time on the global leaderboards, sometimes involving insanely hard skips through parts of the level.

The game has Split Screen and Online multiplayer, both of which work extremely well. The split screen multiplayer has the option to split both horizontally or vertically when playing with only two players. The online multiplayer works extremely well, even with a super high (2-3 second) ping.

The devs are quick to respond to reported bugs, and there is an experimental branch that is updated very frequently, containing the newest bug fixes and content.

The game is very supporting of all types of controllers, from the Xbox 360 controller, to the keyboard, to joysticks. It is super easy to customize the controls to work exactly how you want them to. The game seems to detect and have default settings for all the controllers that I've thrown at it.

I very much recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a fun racing game, to play by themselves or with friends. Distance is fun, competitive, fast-paced, and full of action. I don't believe that there is a better racing game in the world right now.

Currently (Mar 2016) it's looking like they are about to significantly change the game's physics in a VERY bad way...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

**Summary: A very good game to race on, but its level editor needs work, in my opinion.**

Positives:
Excellent graphics
Excellent sound design
Controller support
Racing gameplay feels fantastic to do
Wide variety of community made levels of varying challenges
Thorough options menu with ways to compensate for less powerful rigs

Negatives
Level Editor

I'm not going to devote time to explaining Distance's graphics and whatnot to you, you can see them easily in the trailers, which, from my playing of it, reflect the game as it is. I also will say that I can't stand the keyboard controls for the game, but that's just me. Try it yourself.

This game's main issue (in my opinion, of course) is its level editor.

Don't get me wrong- lots of great levels have been made with it, and there's quite a lot of functionality in it. It's just too bad that that functionality is buried behind a userface I could generously describe as unintuitive"
recommended: trying to perform what ought to be simple actions is made into a frustrating experience by the simple fact that the editor
voteText: does not want to play along.\n\nAnd before you say "There are guides available
helpfulPercent:
I will say that I should not have to go search the internet to figure out how a crucial function of the game works. It would be one thing if I was doing it to see what nifty things others have thought to try or to get ideas for my own designs, but it's a very different matter when I have to do it just to figure out how the editor works. That said, I don't think the problem is unsolvable by any means; I just think the current level editor is not up to scratch.

Overall, I would buy this game to race. The level editor makes building what should be very simple things into an ordeal much too frequently for me to consider it particularly enjoyable.

But the actual racing, flying, jumping and whatnot feel fantastic - though I prefer a controller for it. Then again, apparently top-tier players love the keyboard controls, so I might be in the minority.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nFantastic game.  I always loved Nitronic Rush, but this easily tops it.  You can set up the controls to have control over every little movement and setting you like, or keep it simple and standard. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fantastic level design, high speed tracks that are essentially puzzles, very fitting music, workshop support, being able to mess up so hard that you fly off the track and are able to explore the geometry and even possibly recover, physics based vehicle damage, and a very nice looking cel shading. The only flaw I have is that the Nightmare levels seem a bit out of place.

The ending of Adventure mode stating that more levels coming is great. I love games that seemingly break your hardware, but don't really.

Edit: After owning the game for over a month, the developer is constantly updating and improving the game. This is a great example of early access working.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is very interesting, none the less. Even if your taste is not in racing games, it is a good pass time if you're overwhelmed from playing that Multiplayer game you typically play when you wake up in the morning. God knows when I am annoyed after playing Rust or Counter Strike: Global Offensive that it's these games I like to turn to. Overall, Distance has very many wonderful mechanisms to it. Gravity being a very affected party of this game; you need to understand how the physics of this game works if you want to play it properly. Once you get the hang of everything, however, you start to receive a lot of enjoyment out of playing the maps that are preset in the game, and even custom ones made by the community. Not only does Distance have wonderful mechanics to it, but it also has a nice developmental structure to it, and what I mean by that is it includes its own level editor, and you can make maps, such as a Rainbow Road and a Mario Kart map I've already took the liberty of playing on. I can say that this game is very enjoyable as a I have spare time and I'm not doing too much
date:
type of game. Almost like listening to music or watching Netflix while you're idling in your game server trying to get rid of that TF2 item you don't like.

The only problem I have with this game is the Multiplayer. You have to set up your own server and typically invite people to your game, because there are not a lot of random public servers to play on. They are all typically private for friends or a group of people. If they had a matchmaking feature like Left 4 Dead 2 does, then that would make Multiplayer a bit more appealing in my eyes.

Overall, I do enjoy this game, and hope that it's carried out in development further than what it is now.
Wonderful potential here, just don't end up like a lot of other Early Access games that are, very unfortunately, In early access" for two and a half years and never actually goes anywhere often. Yes
recommended: that was a shot at DayZ. Sorry!"

This game is stupid fun.  The mechanics already in place make it a blast to drive through already.  The track creator and what people have already done with it is awe-inspiring.  This game has the potential to be what Mod-Nation Racers wanted to be: The racer that can be whatever its community wants it to be.

Some things I'd like to see in the future would be player collisions, something of a traditional lap-mode, and some mouse-friendliness through menus.  But mostly, I want to play the game some more.

Early Access Review

Very fun game, i highly recommend a controller or changing the default keyboard controls so the air controls (arrow keys) mirror wasd so you dont have to change hands every time you get airborne to steer and leave the arrow keys solely for turning.


If you use a controller i suggest binding L1 to move right and R1 to move left so that way transitioning onto walls is easier (instead of boost + direction opposite to the wall its now boost + trigger on the side you wish to go)

Other than that unintuitive thing the game is very fun and there are alot of community levels already.
Its definantly worth the price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The most inventive and original racing game I've played in quite some time; Distance is an Incredibly fast and highly-engaging arcade racer with stunning Tron-esque graphics and audio.

The adventure mode is truly unique as you attempt to 'survive' a series of monolithic tracks full of bizarre hazards like buzzsaw blades, laser grids, portals, spaceships and more. There's alot of mechanics to master - like boosting, jumping and flying - but Refract have managed to tie them together in a seamless/rewarding fashion. There's also arcade, multiplayer, track editor and community support so there's plenty to enjoy with Distance in its current Early Access form.

Highly recommended for fans of games like Burnout, Split Second, Need for Speed and TrackMania.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Racing along a track, I dodge the 5 laser-beams trying to cut my car in half. I make it past the 3 saw-blades, spinning in the track. Home free! Oh, a laser across the track - jump over it. Where's the track gone? It's above me... ok, turn on flight mode, perform a 180 rotation in mid-air, and land on the upside-down track. Then it does it again. 180 mid-air rotation.

Now the track is on the side - I need to jump, go to flight mode, and perform a 90-degree turn, before landing on the new track.

The above happened over maybe 15 seconds.

This game is intense. It's beautiful. It's so hardcore it's almost illegal.

The car physics feel a little plastic-ie"
date: but I suspect that's the only way of keeping it moving fast enough to allow me to make such fine and rapid changes during game.\n\nThat's all before we talk about tag mode
hoursPlayed: "football mode" (push the ball into the enemy net)...\n\nAnd the graphics are a mix of superb future / LSD trip."

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

So, this is an extremely unique single-player racing game. It's unique in a good way! With a car that has a rocket on it's butt, and can turn into an aircraft, ride your way to victory on this badass car. You have to dodge lazers, buzzsaws, walls, and hurdles in a futuristic setting. The story is a bit vague; I don't really know what's happening. It has mechanics that make the game easy to learn, but hard to master. I'd recommend playing this with a controller.

But, honestly, the game is kind of easy. The default difficulty for when you first load up the game is expert. And I've played the game twice without even knowing the difficulty level.

But, overall, this is an amazing game, I recommend that you get it when you can, most likely during a sale. The adventure mode still isn't comeplete, and it ends on a really weird note. Hopefully the creators will fix that.

Thank you for reading.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

**Summary: A very good game to race on, but its level editor needs work, in my opinion.**

Positives:
Excellent graphics
Excellent sound design
Controller support
Racing gameplay feels fantastic to do
Wide variety of community made levels of varying challenges
Thorough options menu with ways to compensate for less powerful rigs

Negatives
Level Editor

I'm not going to devote time to explaining Distance's graphics and whatnot to you, you can see them easily in the trailers, which, from my playing of it, reflect the game as it is. I also will say that I can't stand the keyboard controls for the game, but that's just me. Try it yourself.

This game's main issue (in my opinion, of course) is its level editor.

Don't get me wrong- lots of great levels have been made with it, and there's quite a lot of functionality in it. It's just too bad that that functionality is buried behind a userface I could generously describe as unintuitive"
recommended: trying to perform what ought to be simple actions is made into a frustrating experience by the simple fact that the editor
voteText: does not want to play along.\n\nAnd before you say "There are guides available
helpfulPercent:
I will say that I should not have to go search the internet to figure out how a crucial function of the game works. It would be one thing if I was doing it to see what nifty things others have thought to try or to get ideas for my own designs, but it's a very different matter when I have to do it just to figure out how the editor works. That said, I don't think the problem is unsolvable by any means; I just think the current level editor is not up to scratch.

Overall, I would buy this game to race. The level editor makes building what should be very simple things into an ordeal much too frequently for me to consider it particularly enjoyable.

But the actual racing, flying, jumping and whatnot feel fantastic - though I prefer a controller for it. Then again, apparently top-tier players love the keyboard controls, so I might be in the minority.

votesTotal: true
commentsCount: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is very pretty and kinda interesting (if you can have fun alone against the track), I do recommend the game.

But let me warn anyone thinking about getting it for VR: do not get it only for the VR. You will not have a good time.

VR performance is good, works well, interface support is top notch... But the gameplay is not suited for VR. Too many bumps, camera shakes, unpredictable sudden changes of motion, spins in every direction, visual refraction and color distortions, All that very fast. The abstract tracks that curves vertically are nice, but in VR you feel every polygon collision.

Again: the game is great and you should play it, but you do not want it just to increase your VR library.

(disclaimer: please use this review only if it applies to you)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Distance is a mysterious, neon styled racing game set in space, somewhere above earth a long time from now. The general goal is to reach the finish, go fast and avoid various hazards on your way. Your space car comes equipped with a nitro boost that refills when landing stunts or driving through checkpoints, a set of wings that also use your boost meter to fly and a killer suspension system that makes sharp turns and airborne maneuvering easy. The stunt game mode deviates from this general goal as you only rely on GOOD STUFF like doing as many ASTOUNDING stunts as possible in a set amount of time to get you GOIN' THE DISTANCE.

Distance is still in early access but it's already perfectly playable, there just aren't many official levels yet. However, thanks to the level editor and Steam Workshop, you currently have 885 custom made levels at your disposal... plenty of gameplay. So far I've tried several of the higher rated ones and they were all great.

There's also a neat Transmogrify game mode that creates a random map based on what you write. Try super long never ending ride". Spoiler alert: it ends and it's not even that long but it's got a great
date:
sinister atmosphere about it. Everything fits.

The kicking soundtrack fits the game perfectly. There's also an option to import and listen to your own music while you play. There are a lot of options.

That said
recommended: I have a few minor complaints. I think the beatbox sound mode would be better if there was no screen shake and just a bigger emphasis on the blinking lights. I also miss the over the top announcer from Distance's predecessor - Nitronic Rush. I understand that the game is a bit more serious
hoursPlayed: lonesome and mysterious this time around. In fact
voteText: I really dig the whole space neon-machine atmosphere but If they added the announcer as an off by default or at least stunt mode only audio option
helpfulPercent: that'd just make the game BETTER THAN SLICED BREAD."
votesHelpful: September 14, 2015
votesTotal: true

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nNever knew a high-speed obstacle driving game could be atmospheric, even scary, until this. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just finished the 'story' mode in under 2 hours. There is alot of hype surrounding this game - and it is fairly well justified. The graphics are killer, and the music is perfect. Its really fun. There are some cool flying/flipping mechanics that feel great with a controller - overall controls are really tight. Lots of great graphics options too.

My only complaint is the price for the content available now. I am less interested in the level editor right now, but thats a good start. The multiplayer didn't work for me, but I am not knocking the game for that - I didn't try too hard, and it is an indie title.

Overall, this is one of the better race titles I have played in a long time. Even for the steep *ish* price, I don't regret it for a second.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At the time of me writing this review, if the game wasn't labeled as Early Access" I'd absolutely believe it was a finished product.

PROS
Incredibly responsive controls
Excellent original EDM-based soundtrack
Clean menu interface
Tracks included with the vanilla game are solid
Extensive Steam Workshop support
Contains a random track generator (trackmogrify)
Easy to use level editor
Great netcode for multiplayer
CONS
Small community
recommended: sometimes you may not be able to find a reliable multiplayer game.\nMay be unique to my GPU but Motion Blur completely cripples my performance on ANY video settings. Disabling it allows me to max all other settings while keeping a steady 60fps....?\nSpecs: AMD FX-6120
voteText:
12GB RAM

TL;DR Distance is a very well polished racing game with several unique mechanics that should be a dream come true for anyone that ever loved F-Zero. Can't wait to see what the devs add to this game in the future. 9.5/10

Early Access Review\n\nThis game feels  a lot like F-Zero X with a few puzzle elements added.  I highly recommend this game if you have a controller to play with.  I'm using an xbox 360 controller via USB.  Even in its beta state, it is still a lot of fun.  Don't forget to download levels from steam workshop as they can be a lot more challenging.  Also, if you have trouble driving and 'rolling' at the same time, try rebinding some of the default xbox controller buttons.

Early Access Review

Would I recommend this game?  Absolutely.

Whether you're screaming down the track at near, possibly above supersonic speeds in a mad dash to get to the finish line faster than your opponents, executing dazzling and sometimes hypnotizing flips and spins to rack up points and make your peers jealous of your finesse, avoiding buzzsaws, lasers, walls that pop up almost faster than you can react, and a whole mess of other obstacles in place to keep you from your goal, or just taking in all of the atmosphere and laser light shows of this electronica-driven masterpiece, Distance doesn't fail to please on any fronts.  If you're a fan of balls-to-the-wall, high-speed action that demands your full attention and split-second reflexes, I very much implore you to check out this game, you will not be disappointed.

The people who made that game have now gone onto make their own game studio, and are working on this game. Everything about it is an improvement. The controls are more responsive, the level design is more imaginative, and it has an excellent soundtrack that fits thematically. Despite it being an early access game and not being complete, I have had a wonderful experience with the game, and I highly recommend it.
