Early Access Review\n\nThis is a great game to satisfy my need for speed. If you're looking for a game where you can go fast, and do rediculous stuff, this is it. It's a perfect example of a modern take on old style arcade games. I don't care how realistic a game is, as long as it's fun.

Early Access Review

Best early access game i've ever purchased
Ok, if you've ever played (and liked) Nitronic Rush, then you will love Distance. The music is amazing, visuals are extremely good, the game is extremely smooth, as are the controls. There are multiple Game-modes, a level editor and Steam Workshop support, meaning you won't ever run out of levels to play.

The games story and challenge levels are also extremely well designed, with shortcuts, unique levels and a story (which though isn't complete yet is still awesome). If you're like me and enjoy trying to get the best time and rank on each mode, then you will enjoy it. Distance is one of few games that i genuinely enjoy speedrunning levels on.

The game states that it is in early access, so there are some bugs, and the story isn't quite finished. I personally, haven't encountered any bugs, and there are enough levels on the workshop for me not to care so much about the unfinished story. If anything, i look forward to playing new story levels. I can quite happily say that this is the best early access game i have ever purchased.

Early Access Review\n\nIf the controls were a little more solid, and the seed generator created longer maps, this would be one of the greatest arcade racing games to date. The flying and fast-paced and the music and the visuals. This game has amazing potential. New car styles, and maybe a bit more user-control for creating/generating maps. I love this game and would love to see much more come from it.

Early Access Review

Initial first impressions were strange, since the driving feels slower than you'd expect. But once the other mechanics start flying at you, you'll understand why. I'm looking forward to seeing how this comes together.

This game is like Need for madness and Audiosurf combined. You can also ♥♥♥♥ing fly around. As soon as  i saw the trailer i was hooked. This game has alot of potential. Ok, so I spent like 10$ on this game, and believe me, last game I've bought for more than 5$ was probably gta4 around 3 years ago. Why did I do that? Simply because I've fallen in love with its prequel, nitronic rush. You can check it out, i think it's 100% free to download.

Imo, compared to NR, Distance still lacks these perfectly designed, not-so-trivial campaign levels. In return we get unlimited amount of tracks from the community, and some of them are really beautiful, some quite surprising, some surprisingly creative.

Multiplayer works and it's pretty fun, haven't checked splitscreen yet (but it is there).

Also, I can't really imagine playing this game without gamepad. My friend played on keyboard and, while he still had really good time with the game, he couldn't micro his movement while freefalling (or in 0G) that well.

So, my recomendation: Download NR, try it for yourself if you like it, and then throw some money at these guys, because I think they really deserve it.

I don't normally like racing games but this one is just plain awesome. It has a short adventure (story sort of) mode that's going to be expanded in the future, right now it functions as a bit of a showcase and tutorial but it looks like it has great potential to be a really unique single player experience. It has workshop support so there's a whole bunch of user made tracks to download for the various game modes, which I think is one of the best parts of this game. You won't get bored with a lack of tracks any time soon.

The only slight problem I have is that there don't seem to be very many online servers (4 is the most I've seen, 3 being passworded) but I imagine this will be remedied once the player base grows.

Early Access Review

A very abstract-yet-addicting approach to merging both puzzle and driving genres into one new-age racing game.

rundown:
+ amazingly crisp graphics
+ an easy-to-learn level workshop editor with plenty of tutorials
+ A catchy futuristic electronic soundtrack
+ no HUD to block your view (for this kind of game, all you really need is a speed gauge and elapsed time)
+ Your car can freakin' fly/flip/rotate/glide!!!
+ Nice visual damage detailing to your vehicle. (from small dents in your fender to being sliced in half by lasers)
+ You can still continue driving, even with your car diced up in half, as long as you have more than half of your car is intact!

- Car runs somewhat slow without boost and turns/flips over on a dime
- Only one car for the whole game (although it could be a positive thing for people who dislike complicated racing games)


- If you're a racing fan, why are you still reading this? GO BUY IT ALREADY!

Early Access Review

I play Distance with an Oculus Rift, and upon firing it up was initially disappointed by the weird tracks and game mechanics. It's a reaction that I think a lot of players will have at first. But after getting used to the controls, and discovering the random level generator and edited tracks which extend gameplay considerably, I quickly went from disappoint to gleefullly enjoying this game.

In fact, I think I have played this game in VR for longer play sessions than what I usually tolerate with a headset on, including relative to stuff like Elite Dangerous. I could probably play this for an hour or two even with a headset on, if I had the time, as it's easy to lose track of time playing random tracks and seeing what other crazy tricks the game can throw at you. For my part, I did not experiene nausea or stomach churning in VR, and the game does not induce my fear of heights as much as a game like Radial G can.

This isn't to say that the VR implementation is better than in standard establishing games like Elite, cause it's not. In fact, the VR adds less to this game than some others like Elite or Radial G, which feel more like VR can be an integral part of the game, rather than an add-on. But if the VR feels like a nice but not revolutionary addition to this game, it's well implemented enough to at least add to the immersion, and may even make the game a little more playable as you can look up to see oncoming parts of the tricky tracks more easily. Just don't expect the same level of presence that some purpose-built for VR games have.

This is not like other futuristic VR racing games with some obstacles and the occasional surprise, like the excellent Radial G. It's also not like traditional racers such as the also excellent Project Cars. At least for now, there don't seem to be computer controlled opponents, which is a bit of a disappointment. But what keeps the game interesting is that the game's tracks are, essentially, trying to kill you.

While you generally have a chance to respond to things as they occur enough so that absolute track memorization is not necessary, things do start to feel a bit like a puzzle game all the same as you learn to navigate using a mix of odd car abilities from jumping to even flying. Yeah, flying. This game forces you to try all kinds of crazy stunts in order to survive each track's tricky obstacles, including lasers, saw blades, moving walls, and the need to wall climb or fly to reach other levels. At first, this can be frustrating. But it can soon become quite engaging as it all starts to make a weird sort of sense. A gamepad is recommended.

And the tracks really are trying to get you. In one random level I generated, a bot-like moving wall hovered above me, following my car until it could pounce down in front of me at just the right moment to score a kill. That's one tricky obstacle! You quickly learn not to take anything for granted while playing this game, as it's more of a survival challenge rather than a conventional racing game. Not all jumps are good to take, turns that look sensible can get you killed, and there are tracks where, instead of only being able to turn left or right at a fork in the road, you also have the option to take a jump right down the middle. Which path is right for you? You can play repeatedly to find out! Come for the pretty colors and Tron-like graphics, and stay for the addictive gameplay.

Early Access Review\n\nThis game is an awesome survival-racing game set in a virtual, computer like world. It is a spiritual succesor to Nitronic Rush (which is free game that you can play if you aren't sure about buying this game). Your goal is to race to the finish line as fast as possible while avoiding death traps like buzz saws, lasers, or a variety of other deadly things. It also has local and online multiplayer. It is a very fun game, which I highly recommend! 8.5/10

Early Access Review

This is shaping up to be a very fun little game. The art design and music are great so far, the city has a distinctly Tron-like aesthetic and the music in each stage really brings out the atmosphere. Despite having no story to speak of it's stages string together a visual narrative that not only keeps you from getting bored but brings out a modicum of emotion as well. The tracks are well composed, nothing is unfairly unforgiving and one is rarely left scratching his head while stuck somewhere wondering what he's supposed to do. All in all I'm excited to see the final product.

My only major complaint is the controls, or rather the way the game introduces you to them. Early on if you are using an XBOX controller it instructs you to use A to boost and X to jump. And early on this is fine, later you also need to quickly use the right stick which proves difficult. What the game doesn't tell you is that you can also use the shoulder buttons for boost and jump freeing your right thumb to do the tricky bits. But relearning the controls half way through the main game is kind of annoying. (As the game is in development this may all change)

Early Access Review

Wow, this is such a cool more-than-just-an-arcade-style-racing game!
I only just dipped a toe in, so will revise my review once i've clocked an unhealthy amount of hours in it :D
Great music!
Some of the best transitions between physics environments (or however to word that) i've seen in a long time ... flying over to a wall and then riding that ... so unique.
The car is AWESOME.
Flight controls via keyboard almost made me hurl at first, so instead of trying to fight through it, I switched over to my Xbox controller and picked up the flight style quite quickly after that.

The levels in the story mode so far are wonderfully weird. I just experienced a crazy section where i was warped through the same section a couple times by some tear in time or something, around some sort of experiment that appeared to go wrong, at times leaving the world in ruins ... pretty amazing stuff for what on the surface appears to be just a tron-esque racing game.

Even at its Beta status it's looking to be a winner and plenty worth the chunk of money to help support a really cool project. I'm glad I gave it a shot ... i've got almost 200 games in my Library awaiting my hard won attention and I HAPPILY downloaded and played this game moments after purchase.

Early Access Review

Highly recommended. Maybe the best racing game on Linux. If you ever wanted to race with a futuristic car in a very futuristic world, this game is for you! Its racing with a twist, your car can perform various new functions such as jumping, wallriding and even flying! All this makes for very interesting race courses where the quickest way sometimes requires a lot of creativity. Something like extreme-G mixed with Trackmania.

Graphics and sound are excellent, but my favourite part is the gameplay. The car really controls so well, it is even possible to play with the keyboard. Good control is important as the game requires lighting fast reactions.

Note there are no AI oponents, hopefully this is something that will be added later. I had a lot of fun playing with random people through multiplayer though. The split screen option is also a very welcome addition and this can very easily be a fun game to play when having friends over. Just make sure to find an easy level pack first as most of the default levels take a lot of practice to master.

column22: and his works eith every game imaginable. Clearing up a few ports to host a server is one thing

Early Access Review

I've been fooled by quite a few games on Early Access and become quite hesitant to even purchase them anymore. But I have to say this is one of the few gems inside of this program. Distance is just plain addicting. I can just spend hours on end replaying the same levels (Or going through the library of community made tracks on the workshop! ) over and over again. The car itself is amazing allowing you to boost, jump, fly and rotate giving you many options for sick tricks that you can do. The teleporters I have to say is another one of my favorite things about this game, nothing is as  cool as doing a flip through a teleporter and dodging multiple blades and lazers before landing it or suddenly being taken to an area with Zero Gravity or where you're upside down. Did I mention that the car also lets you ride on walls and ceilings? This game is fast paced, and very awesome if you can stay up to speed and stick to your reactions as you dodge anything that blocks your path. It has multiplayer already in the game from the get go which works pretty well for an Early Access game so far. The game also lets you customize your car to a limited extent along with an easy, but deep level editor. Also if you were wondering, you can go first person as well! There's no interior just the front of the car but holy ♥♥♥♥ it's tough but cool as hell to drive in that view. Recommend this game to any of your friends if you own it, this needs a larger community to support it!

tl;dr: Game is like hotwheels, and trackmania with it's own little twists (Teleporter, and the car.) Very fun, awesome tricks. If you've been hesitant on buying it, don't hold back.

I'd give this game personally a 10/10. Can't really find anything I don't enjoy about it. It's one of those fun, addicting little games you find that you can't put down and keep coming back to. Going from highspeed races, to doing sick stunts with your friends, along with making a level or two if you have the creativity and time. This game has quite a bit of content and love put into it for only being out for just under two months. I can't wait to see where it goes.

Early Access Review\n\nHarken back to the days of pure unbridaled joy, like being back in SF Rush stunt tracks with boosters and wings! I love this game. played 3 hours straight last night and more today at work. 10/10 would play again.

Early Access Review\n\nIn simplest terms this game is to mario kart the same way super meat boy is to super mario bros and the level editor is to hotwheels like how mincraft is to lego. Remember that jumping mechanic from mario kart 64? Well imagine that, but with gravity changing to whatever surface your bottom is facing with the freedom to control your midair positioning and even an option to boost/fly at any time depending on the levels. The level editor can be tricky at first, but becomes very useful once you are familiar with it. So much potential for this game and, just like the races, there is no way of telling where this is going to go. 10/10 I could not be more excited for the full release.

Early Access Review

This Distance is a fast and intense action survival racing game, where you drive agens other unique players in advanced atmospheric worlds.

Have you ever wanted to be in that Tron legacy world with laser, future and amazing cool music? Well, here is your chance to live it in a car and do alot of driving, jumping, spinning, flying, avoiding insane traps and tracks.

The game has a unique design of it's own, where the Tron legacy atmospheric world makes your hearth beat faster. Overall controlls with either keyboard or controller is simple to use, where you get a decent movement of your car. The game allows you to spin, jump, fly and drive with a health bar that might overheat to destroy you. Every map or custom map through workshop has checkpoints that resets/cooling it down.

The music is fantastic, and makes you play all day, unfortunately the game has not unlocked the rest of the singleplayer, since it's in progress. The singleplayer campagin on the other hand throws you straight to basic's and into a interesting world of escape.

Here is a demo:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1u4QOEohzx0

Early Access Review

This game will make you re-imagine everything you thought you knew about racing games.

It's an art game in its own right: a total genre-bender. It's like TRON meets Blade Runner
meets Black Rock City at night. It's hard not to get lost in the visuals.
Graphic are breathtaking, even at lower settings (for those of us who don't want to turn
our slow laptops into molten metal). Speaking of molten metal, the lasers are merciless,
and thoroughly awesome. You can slice your car in half down the plane of symmetry and
still recover if you can steer your glowing hunk of car thru a green regeneration hoop.

Gameplay is intense but forgiving, even for the casual gamer like me who's a novice at
racing games and flight simulators. Skills like the 90° wall jumps, mid-air rotation, coming
into and out of a glide, etc. take practice, but they won't frustrate you into rage-quitting.

My only complaint is that it has all EDM/techno-style music, which can get droning and
repetitive (in my opinion). That's part of the ambiance that the artists wished to convey,
and I respect them for it, but I leave the music turned off.

Early Access Review

So.. what is Distance?

It is the result of combining techno-style lighting and (damn nice!) soundtrack with action-filled and absolutely epic gameplay, all packed into GORGEOUS graphics and futuristic atmosphere.

You see that curvy road twisting around itself? A bit behind the others, are we? Well, how about we friggin FLY ABOVE AND BELOW THE DAMN TRACK TO GIVE OURSELVES SOME ADVANTAGE?!
Oh, and while we're doing that, let's do a barrel roll!

And honestly, if it wouldn't say so, I'd never have guessed this is Early Access!

Pros! Brilliant Soundtrack
Gorgeous Graphics
Action-packed and fun gameplay
Barrel Rolls!
Jumping cars with wings and lights and... stuff
Darude - Sandstorm
Cons The Level Editor is... complex. Very powerful indeed, but you have to get used to it.
No actual Darude - Sandstorm.
This game is fan-♥♥♥♥in-tastic!

Early Access Review

Took a gamble on this, being that it's early access, but I was absolutely blown away by how complete the game felt.
[Gameplay]
+Hyper-fast racing, very similar to Track Mania with San Francisco Rush: 2049 mixed in
+Tons of different track options. You could be driving one second, flying the next, then flipping sideways to wall ride
+You will die often, and the spawn system is quick enough to keep you from getting bored
+These tracks can be very challenging, so you will feel a real sense of accomplishment once you've survived them

[PC Options]
+This is clearly a PC game, with full blown graphics settings options, high framerate, and controller support too
+Custom tracks galore, there are tons already and the game isn't even released yet
-No mouse input at menus as I write this, but it's obvious this is a feature that is intended to be there

[Style]
+Hot damn, it's like tron blew a load in your face
+Impressive visuals, actually manages to make me say wow"
+Soundtrack is excellent
date: it really fits the game perfectly and makes every track feel intense\n\nI really have nothing negative to say so far. If you like racing and you like crazy Tron/flying cars this game is excellent."

Early Access Review

This is an oddball. I purchased this on a whim during the Christmas sale and was pleasantly surprised. This is a small Alpha version of a high octane Wipeouty influenced alternate dystopian reality racer. Whew.

Honestly I have no idea what it is. It's basically an insanely fast racer where twitch reflexes reign supreme. The game itself is quickly easy to master and theres only one car that comes in a few different colors. The official track selection is rather small too but theres a massive amount of great user made tracks free for download on the Steam Workshop.

To be honest the creators rarely ever update this game, and I honestly never see this coming out of early access but it's a cheap thrill to be had and an okay overall experience. I wouldn't pay over $10USD for it though. Buy it on sale.

Early Access Review

A brilliant, beautiful, yet chaotic, survival-racing game. I've never had so much fun in a game that involved just driving before. Completely stunning visuals, trippy elements and unique tracks and obstacles will take your breath away. There was actually a point in time where I felt like the game gave me an artificial high, that's how intense the game really is. I also find that you probably don't have to like racing games in order to like this game, I myself enjoy very few racing games. Distance also has a huge sense of freedom, for there is currently no countdown timer and no limited amount of lives. Checkpoints are plenty and there's also plenty of room to recover from mistakes, if the mistakes aren't disasterous. A superb soundtrack, similar to that of Tron: Legacy's sets the perfect mood for this cyberpunk, dystopian simulation. I highly recommend anyone to at least try this game while the price is still low.

Keep in mind that it is still in Early Access, but after finishing the currently built Story mode and some Online Arcade, I haven't really seen any bugs.

Current Overall Early Access rating: 9.5/10

Early Access Review

I've been fooled by quite a few games on Early Access and become quite hesitant to even purchase them anymore. But I have to say this is one of the few gems inside of this program. Distance is just plain addicting. I can just spend hours on end replaying the same levels (Or going through the library of community made tracks on the workshop! ) over and over again. The car itself is amazing allowing you to boost, jump, fly and rotate giving you many options for sick tricks that you can do. The teleporters I have to say is another one of my favorite things about this game, nothing is as  cool as doing a flip through a teleporter and dodging multiple blades and lazers before landing it or suddenly being taken to an area with Zero Gravity or where you're upside down. Did I mention that the car also lets you ride on walls and ceilings? This game is fast paced, and very awesome if you can stay up to speed and stick to your reactions as you dodge anything that blocks your path. It has multiplayer already in the game from the get go which works pretty well for an Early Access game so far. The game also lets you customize your car to a limited extent along with an easy, but deep level editor. Also if you were wondering, you can go first person as well! There's no interior just the front of the car but holy ♥♥♥♥ it's tough but cool as hell to drive in that view. Recommend this game to any of your friends if you own it, this needs a larger community to support it!

tl;dr: Game is like hotwheels, and trackmania with it's own little twists (Teleporter, and the car.) Very fun, awesome tricks. If you've been hesitant on buying it, don't hold back.

I'd give this game personally a 10/10. Can't really find anything I don't enjoy about it. It's one of those fun, addicting little games you find that you can't put down and keep coming back to. Going from highspeed races, to doing sick stunts with your friends, along with making a level or two if you have the creativity and time. This game has quite a bit of content and love put into it for only being out for just under two months. I can't wait to see where it goes.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAs a programmer, I can appreciate how much time, effort, and stress goes into a project of this magnitude with a team as small as Refract. As a result, the game took quite a while to be released. However, it was well worth the wait- they did an amazing job! The level editor is my favorite part. Refract's strategy of utilizing their growing fanbase really makes this game unique. There are hundreds of tracks for this game from different people and their different ideas, rather than a team of a few people making tracks for their own game. The game is also really easy to learn, even if you haven't played their first game, and it is more than a racing game. There are other exciting game modes. There is a fast-paced survival aspect to each race with tons of obstacles that you need to avoid or your car will be torn to shreds. But each race is only as hard as you want it to be! Purchase the game and you will see what I mean. I want to recommend this game to anyone and everyone, and if anyone at Refract stumbles upon this review, I want to let you know you really knocked it out of the park this time! Great game!

Entertaining for hours.

Overall a good early access version of a game.

Hope to see more coming."

I give it ... Five Stars!

If you're thinkin about getting it, get it!

This is actually my first time posting a review of any kind, and that should say something.  I saw this game on the store page, bought it, and it was worth every penny.  This game is perfect for someone who is looking for a racing game but wants to step away from the traditional stick-shifter, and move in the direction of a sci-fi obstacle course where your pilot a highly advanced supercar equipped for land, air, and zero gravity travel!  It made me think of Sonic All-Stars and maybe the baby of Kario Kart and Portal or something.  I've never seen anything like it, very original gameplay and you can even make your own levels.  I just recently purchased the game and I've spent seven hours on it.  Refract did an amazing job and I wish them the best of luck! If I could make a request for the next update; pick up items for versus style gameplay, and a shuffle option for maps! That would be pretty radical.

One last thing, the introduction video was very exciting and I actually saw a huge potential for storyline development.  I'm eager to see where it goes, I know you guys won't disappoint!

P.s., It was awesome.


Edit: I noticed the design for the car would actually be usable design for an all terrain sports car.  Just thought I would add that and cross my fingers that someone might comment regarding the car's design.

There is a fast-paced survival aspect to each race with tons of obstacles that you need to avoid or your car will be torn to shreds. But each race is only as hard as you want it to be! Purchase the game and you will see what I mean. I want to recommend this game to anyone and everyone, and if anyone at Refract stumbles upon this review, I want to let you know you really knocked it out of the park this time! Great game!

Early Access Review

Though there's not much to the game at it's current state, this game is a really fun experimental survival racing experience. If you've never played nitronic rush before, I would highly recommend giving it a try because it shares a very simmilar playing style. this game features racing at 999999999 Km/h, Being cut into five peices and still being able to get to the next checkpoint, various gravity shifts, flying a car, super mega turbo jets of doom and last but not least, customizable car... colours. (I really hope they add in a actual custom cars thing though.) This game was a great experience for me. There's also a great active community supplying levels left and right. Is it worth 22 bucks? some people will say yes and some people will say -Eesh-. Like I said, there's not much to the game as of this review, it is still in a very early state of developpement but has the potential to grow.... SO much.

UPDATE:
After playing more, I've realized that there is some severe problems in terms of taxing a GPU. for example, on some levels I get sub 50 fps though I clearly should run that slow considering I have an overclocked Radeon 7970 that can run almost anything at 60 fps no problem. this game shouldn't be an exeption especially with it not that stunning graphics. IN SHORT: people with low-end graphics solutions should wait this out until there is some better graphics optimisations.

If Nitronic Rush was Narbacular Drop, then this is Portal... 2.

Everything about Nitronic Rush has been given a staggering upgrade. The controls are dialed-in just right, the level layouts have very obviously been playtested extensively. I've played the game for less than two hours  and completed most of the currently standing content. Now this isn't a bad thing, I spent a huge amount of time playing Nitronic Rush, so that counts as experience. The new player will not be able to breeze through what's there anywhere near as quickly. And on top of that, the game is still in beta so there's clearly lots more planned. There are still a few minor things that need polish/explanation, mostly on the UI side of things. But the game underneath is absolutely incredible.

Missing out on this game is doing yourself a disservice. Don't make that mistake.

Early Access Review

Distance is a high-octane reaction-based arcade racing game set in what I can only assume to be a computer program with a sick EDM (primarily techno) soundtrack to go with it. A spiritual successor to Nitronic Rush, you have only seconds to react to what's in front of you and sometimes not even that much time is given. While sometimes frustrating with no particular payoff other than beating your times, Distance is an exciting game with a cool setting and a great soundtrack.

Gameplay: 8.5/10: Distance offers a variety of game modes including a short campaign, arcade sprint, stunt and style races, versus race, and split-screen up to four players. Each gameplay mode, outside of the multiplayer, is mildly lacking in replay value (unless you're a perfectionist and want to get to the top of the leaderboards which I personally could easily see myself attempting). When you enter the multiplayer it becomes an insane race for first, style points, or who can pull off the most wicked stunt. The last time I felt a game play this smooth and fun was Split/Second and that's what this game reminds me of... only if it were set in Tron.

Graphics: 8/10: The setting is stunning and the tracks are intense to race on. Neon colours flash past you as you go from 0-250mph in just a few short seconds and the environment keeps up with the action you experience. However, upon closer inspection the environment isn't the most detailed setting, with speed of levels (no laps) and need for concentration aiding in the distractability from the environment itself. The car itself is physically stunning and fun to look at, particularly when you activate the thrusters or flight ability. When it explodes for the umpteenth time, you might be a little remorse at the fact that it constantly splits into the same fractal polygons and rains over the landscape below, but if you can get over that sort of thing you might just find yourself immersed in the reactive world around you, which brings us to our next point.

Sound: 9/10: Arguably the star of the game is the notion that the environment reacts to the pumping techno beats and seems to simulate a synesthetic experience. The developers turn sound into visuals which vastly aid in drawing you in to the overall experience. I even found myself reacting and driving to the beat, which for some reason was always perfectly timed to the rest of the level, even if you were to crash with a digitally explosive sound. The soundtrack is genuinely something I find myself coming back to the game to enjoy over and over and over again. The car sounds beautiful and is perfectly matched to its sporty design. I keep returning to the game just to hear the music again and again. I love it that much!

Last Words
Distance is a fun game for perfectionists but if you're into unlocks and specials outside of what you purchase, you'll want to look elsewhere. A visual and audible synesthetic experience that draws you in, Distance is the perfect spiritual successor to some of the most fast-paced and intense racing games on the market.

8.5/10 - Give it a go, especially if you catch it on sale!

I've been on Steam for a while, and this is my first time bothering to write a review.

This game is absorbing.  It's the game that I've been waiting for someone to make.  It's essentially a music-based racer, and it instantly reminded me of Rez from PS2 and XBLA, thrown together with elements of Burnout 3 and the original Extreme-G on the N64 (yea, I'm old).  The music is intense, the graphics are awesome, and the difficulty is just right.  However, the thing that kept me interested for a solid hour was the sense of exploration.  You'll keep playing just to see what happens next in terms of gameplay, track design and music, and the game keeps delivering.

Highly recommended.

Early Access Review

A brilliant, beautiful, yet chaotic, survival-racing game. I've never had so much fun in a game that involved just driving before. Completely stunning visuals, trippy elements and unique tracks and obstacles will take your breath away. There was actually a point in time where I felt like the game gave me an artificial high, that's how intense the game really is. I also find that you probably don't have to like racing games in order to like this game, I myself enjoy very few racing games. Distance also has a huge sense of freedom, for there is currently no countdown timer and no limited amount of lives. Checkpoints are plenty and there's also plenty of room to recover from mistakes, if the mistakes aren't disasterous. A superb soundtrack, similar to that of Tron: Legacy's sets the perfect mood for this cyberpunk, dystopian simulation. I highly recommend anyone to at least try this game while the price is still low.

Keep in mind that it is still in Early Access, but after finishing the currently built Story mode and some Online Arcade, I haven't really seen any bugs.

Current Overall Early Access rating: 9.5/10

Wow, this is such a cool more-than-just-an-arcade-style-racing game!
I only just dipped a toe in, so will revise my review once i've clocked an unhealthy amount of hours in it :D
Great music!
Some of the best transitions between physics environments (or however to word that) i've seen in a long time ... flying over to a wall and then riding that ... so unique.
The car is AWESOME.
Flight controls via keyboard almost made me hurl at first, so instead of trying to fight through it, I switched over to my Xbox controller and picked up the flight style quite quickly after that.

The levels in the story mode so far are wonderfully weird. I just experienced a crazy section where i was warped through the same section a couple times by some tear in time or something, around some sort of experiment that appeared to go wrong, at times leaving the world in ruins ... pretty amazing stuff for what on the surface appears to be just a tron-esque racing game.

Even at its Beta status it's looking to be a winner and plenty worth the chunk of money to help support a really cool project. I'm glad I gave it a shot ... i've got almost 200 games in my Library awaiting my hard won attention and I HAPPILY downloaded and played this game moments after purchase.

Took a gamble on this, being that it's early access, but I was absolutely blown away by how complete the game felt.
[Gameplay]
+Hyper-fast racing, very similar to Track Mania with San Francisco Rush: 2049 mixed in
+Tons of different track options. You could be driving one second, flying the next, then flipping sideways to wall ride
+You will die often, and the spawn system is quick enough to keep you from getting bored
+These tracks can be very challenging, so you will feel a real sense of accomplishment once you've survived them

[PC Options]
+This is clearly a PC game, with full blown graphics settings options, high framerate, and controller support too
+Custom tracks galore, there are tons already and the game isn't even released yet
-No mouse input at menus as I write this, but it's obvious this is a feature that is intended to be there

[Style]
+Hot damn, it's like tron blew a load in your face
+Impressive visuals, actually manages to make me say wow"
+Soundtrack is excellent
date: it really fits the game perfectly and makes every track feel intense\n\nI really have nothing negative to say so far. If you like racing and you like crazy Tron/flying cars this game is excellent."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A very abstract-yet-addicting approach to merging both puzzle and driving genres into one new-age racing game.

rundown:
+ amazingly crisp graphics
+ an easy-to-learn level workshop editor with plenty of tutorials
+ A catchy futuristic electronic soundtrack
+ no HUD to block your view (for this kind of game, all you really need is a speed gauge and elapsed time)
+ Your car can freakin' fly/flip/rotate/glide!!!
+ Nice visual damage detailing to your vehicle. (from small dents in your fender to being sliced in half by lasers)
+ You can still continue driving, even with your car diced up in half, as long as you have more than half of your car is intact!

- Car runs somewhat slow without boost and turns/flips over on a dime
- Only one car for the whole game (although it could be a positive thing for people who dislike complicated racing games)


- If you're a racing fan, why are you still reading this? GO BUY IT ALREADY!

Early Access Review

I've been following this game since they started the kickstarter a while back, which is actually the first and only game I've helped kickstart. I've played from the alpha stage up to now, and the game has shown significant progress. I know a lot of people are hesitant to purchase early access games, but trust me, Refract absolutely know what they are doing with Distance. They have been putting out consistent updates and improvements to the alpha and beta stages over the past year or two, and it is easy to tell that they are very passionate about this game. They also are very supportive of the community, evidenced by the fact they acknowledge and support the user created levels in the workshop.

If I hadn't helped kickstarted this game, I would definitely purchase early access. I really trust Refract with creating a quality game, and I can tell you with certainty that this won't be an early access game that crashes and burns like a lot of others out there.

Also, if you're not sure you like arcade racing games like this, you should download Nitronic Rush, which Distance is the sequel to.  It has very similar mechanics, an awesome soundtrack, and is free! Go try it out!

Early Access Review

This game is incredible, especially for a beta. $20 is a steal for this game right now, and it's only going to get better.

Pros: Looks REALLY good (Like seriously, I took about 5 screenshots to set as desktop backgrounds). Controls are tight for both Keyboard and 360 controller. Good ammount of single player and local Co-Op game modes. Very challenging. The adventure/ story mode builds up the difficulty at a nice pace so there is no terrible difficulty curve. Includes a level editor (Haven't played around with it much, but I love to see that, and from what I've seen it looks very good). Well optomized, runs nicely.

Cons: At a certain point in a certain level, for some reason that I have yet to figure out, the flight mode controls get really iffy, on keyboard at least.

Other thoughts: I run the game on max settings with a nice 75 - 112 FPS, however, if I even turn the real-time reflections onto LOW, the highest my FPS will go is 45. I assume however that this is most likely becuase that feature is very resource intensive, and not due to poor optomization.

Overall, THIS GAME IS A MUST BUY, great game, if this was a finished game I would be happy with the purchase, but it's still only in beta!! I can't wait for further updates, and I wish all the luck in the world to the developers.

Early Access Review

Note: this game is early access, so don't expect a FULL game.

Personally, it reminds me of the classic Wipeout games, so I really love it! Fast action, sci-fi theme, sick graphics and a decent audio track!

Why I liked it:
- Wall climbing! Gravity here is for fools!
- Mind-blowing levels! The sci-fi theme it's really well done!
- Flying! Did I mention anything about gravity?
- Fast action! No thinking twice, be prepared or smash your face on that wall!
- Level editor! Potentially infinite maps!

What it lacks:
- More cars
- More multiplayer gamemodes
- Power-ups, weapons and more stuff for better arcade and multiplayer
- Decent SFX, for now the game seems just too quiet

Overall, great game, and I'm sure they will add a good part of what I think it lacks!

Early Access Review

Ok, before you buy this game, go play Nitronic Rush. If you like that you will like this.

Distance is a Tron-esqe racing game where you speed along floating roads and fly through obstacles at very high speeds.

Gameplay-10/10
The gameplay in Distance is absolutely flawless. The controls feel fluid and are very responsive, and I know that I am in control of my car at all times. The gameplay consists of driving along roads at high speeds while dodging obstacles like buzzsaws, lasers, walls, spinning cylinders of death spikes, and so on. While you usually just drive along roads, you also can fly. Everything about the driving and flying is great. There is also a boost system that reminds me of Excite Truck, which was my favorite racing game until I got Distance. Also, if you get cut by lasers, you can still drive with half of your car. That's probably my favorite thing in Distance.

Story-N/A
The adventure mode isn't finished yet, so I can't really review it right now.

Multiplayer-10/10
I haven't encountered any lag in multiplayer yet. You have to get to the finish as fast as possible, trying to beat the other players. However, the other players appear as ghosts and cannot effect your vehicle, making the race into more of a synonomous time trial.

Graphics-10/10
The graphics remind me of Nitronic Rush, but have a glossy new feel that fits with the atmosphere very well.

Overall-10/10
For what it is, Distance is a fantastic game. Even though it is essentially a remake of Nitronic Rush, it does everything right. It runs well on lower spec PCs, you can play it on Mac and Linux as well as PC, there's a level editor with workshop support. Just keep in mind that it is a racing game.

Early Access Review\n\nA classic in the making. Distance seems to meld the twitchy perfection of racers like Trackmania (with an even more intuitive map builder) with the classic, hyperactive rush of old school arcade racers. If you yearn for the days of Wipeout, POD, MegaRace, and STUN Runner, this is a ticket back to those wild, futuristic flight racers.

I've played a fair few early access games in 2014, and many of them make me hate to see the words 'EARLY ACCESS GAME' on a store page. Distance is a pleasing diversion from this norm, for beta the game has excellent flow and re-playability, not based on a catalouge of features, but simply wanting to do it better each time. Early Access Review\n\nWho liked Xtreme G on N64 or Blur on PC or is simply bored by the similarity of current racing games will love this. It's a survival sci-fi racing game with reaaaally nice gameplay features and a smooth electronic bouncing sound. I kept my head nodding while trying to keep up with the fast pace of actions some tracks demand from you. BAM! NICE GAME! ABSOLUTELY RECOMMENDED!

Early Access Review

This game will make you re-imagine everything you thought you knew about racing games.

It's an art game in its own right: a total genre-bender. It's like TRON meets Blade Runner
meets Black Rock City at night. It's hard not to get lost in the visuals.
Graphic are breathtaking, even at lower settings (for those of us who don't want to turn
our slow laptops into molten metal). Speaking of molten metal, the lasers are merciless,
and thoroughly awesome. You can slice your car in half down the plane of symmetry and
still recover if you can steer your glowing hunk of car thru a green regeneration hoop.

Gameplay is intense but forgiving, even for the casual gamer like me who's a novice at
racing games and flight simulators. Skills like the 90° wall jumps, mid-air rotation, coming
into and out of a glide, etc. take practice, but they won't frustrate you into rage-quitting.

My only complaint is that it has all EDM/techno-style music, which can get droning and
repetitive (in my opinion). That's part of the ambiance that the artists wished to convey,
and I respect them for it, but I leave the music turned off.

Early Access Review

This game does everything right. I usually don't play racing games (I have none on my steam account), but I decided to pick this one up. The atmosphere, the colour, the mystery, and the overall mind-bending aspects of this game make it my favourite game that I've gotten so far.

At first glance, it will just seem like a colourful driving game, but seriously, I have found EVERYTHING that I've wanted in a racing game here, it's fast paced, challenging (but not too difficult once you get into it), and certain aspects like spinning around to jump on upside-down surfaces, or suddenly having the gravity turn off and learning to adjust your playstyle make it super addictive

This game is also packed with lore, but it's never explicitly shoved in your face. The story mode seems to be about some kind of society that released... something, but that's all I've been able to figure out so far. I don't want to spoil anything either, but every detail of the adventure mode is packed with information about what happened. The adventure mode makes me feel like I'm delving into the past, trying to uncover what happened to this society. I've actually played the adventure mode three times now just because of how awesome it feels, it's so fun, and there are a lot of parts that feel so ominous, like I'm watching the end of the world but I don't entirely understand how it happened. The starting cut scene, that just shows the car starting, gives tons of information on the story, but you won't realize it unless you play it through again, and even the loading screens give you a glimpse into what is going on

Overall I am thoroughly impressed with this game. Every aspect of it comes together to make a masterpiece. One thing I'd recommend is making sure you have the right hardware to be able to run it, because the game is just so freaking awesome and having any sort of lag would take away from the experience (you can change the visual settings and that does help, but again the game looks so amazing on full quality)

10/10, I can't wait to see this game when it's completely finished, despite how polished it is already

This is a great racing game that reminds me of TrackMania Nations Forever, but with so much content added to it. It requires skill like trackmania but adds a level of control to it that is incredible. This game has it all, jumping, flying, directional thrusters, zero g maps, very well done glitch effects, crazy obstacles that can cut your car into chunks, and regeneration checkpoints. The tools on the car are great fun and also allow you to recover in incredible ways that would otherwise make this game a demanding test to always play perfectly.

This game runs great and the only minor issue I had was with the keymapping on my logitech gamepad.

Racing games usually aren't my thing, but Distance does to racing what a mescaline overdose does to an adolescent polar bear.
It's one of the trippiest cyber-punk dystopia racing games i've ever seen, with an awesome soundtrack to boot!
The game runs quite nicely, and that's usually because the game does not have an over-abundance of clutter, just buildings and racing hazards.
There are several different gamemodes to choose from, but my favorite is sprint, where you have to finish the track as fast as you can.
The game will send you into spirals, climbing up walls, and flying. Yes, flying, not the kind of flying where you are in the air for a period of time and then land but....wait that is flying, anyways, your car doors turn into wings" and you go "whoosh!"
And yes

Wow, this is such a cool more-than-just-an-arcade-style-racing game!
I only just dipped a toe in, so will revise my review once i've clocked an unhealthy amount of hours in it :D
Great music!
Some of the best transitions between physics environments (or however to word that) i've seen in a long time ... flying over to a wall and then riding that ... so unique.
The car is AWESOME.
Flight controls via keyboard almost made me hurl at first, so instead of trying to fight through it, I switched over to my Xbox controller and picked up the flight style quite quickly after that.

The levels in the story mode so far are wonderfully weird. I just experienced a crazy section where i was warped through the same section a couple times by some tear in time or something, around some sort of experiment that appeared to go wrong, at times leaving the world in ruins ... pretty amazing stuff for what on the surface appears to be just a tron-esque racing game.

Even at its Beta status it's looking to be a winner and plenty worth the chunk of money to help support a really cool project. I'm glad I gave it a shot ... i've got almost 200 games in my Library awaiting my hard won attention and I HAPPILY downloaded and played this game moments after purchase.

I would definitely recommend Distance to anyone who's looking for something different.
First, some history: Distance was funded on Kickstarter in 2012. The team consists of many if the developers who worked on the game Nitronic Rush. Enough history.
Distance doesn't truly fall into any one category, with its multitude of game modes, and openness to really just do whatever you want in any mode. With the level editor, you can create the race track of your dreams or make a playground for some high-octane parkour.
And no matter what you decide to do in Distance, you'll be doing it to a bad-♥♥♥ soundtrack.

Couldn't care less about Tron as I never experienced the golden side of it (Not to take away from those who do love it though), so that side does not contribute to my love of this game.

Anyway, onto the review. I've only played for a short time but I can see this becoming one of my favourite racing games. The flight adds such strategy to overtaking, making you have to watch the road for obstacles, and the sky for rivals.
You have to time jump, direct flight, dodge lasers, jump from road to road. Plus a great boost system of cool down by passing through gates instead of having to earn it on the go.

Can't wait to play a local game with friends and watch the ensuing chaos

Early Access Review

I've been following this game since they started the kickstarter a while back, which is actually the first and only game I've helped kickstart. I've played from the alpha stage up to now, and the game has shown significant progress. I know a lot of people are hesitant to purchase early access games, but trust me, Refract absolutely know what they are doing with Distance. They have been putting out consistent updates and improvements to the alpha and beta stages over the past year or two, and it is easy to tell that they are very passionate about this game. They also are very supportive of the community, evidenced by the fact they acknowledge and support the user created levels in the workshop.

If I hadn't helped kickstarted this game, I would definitely purchase early access. I really trust Refract with creating a quality game, and I can tell you with certainty that this won't be an early access game that crashes and burns like a lot of others out there.

Also, if you're not sure you like arcade racing games like this, you should download Nitronic Rush, which Distance is the sequel to.  It has very similar mechanics, an awesome soundtrack, and is free! Go try it out!

Early Access Review

This game is incredible, especially for a beta. $20 is a steal for this game right now, and it's only going to get better.

Pros: Looks REALLY good (Like seriously, I took about 5 screenshots to set as desktop backgrounds). Controls are tight for both Keyboard and 360 controller. Good ammount of single player and local Co-Op game modes. Very challenging. The adventure/ story mode builds up the difficulty at a nice pace so there is no terrible difficulty curve. Includes a level editor (Haven't played around with it much, but I love to see that, and from what I've seen it looks very good). Well optomized, runs nicely.

Cons: At a certain point in a certain level, for some reason that I have yet to figure out, the flight mode controls get really iffy, on keyboard at least.

Other thoughts: I run the game on max settings with a nice 75 - 112 FPS, however, if I even turn the real-time reflections onto LOW, the highest my FPS will go is 45. I assume however that this is most likely becuase that feature is very resource intensive, and not due to poor optomization.

Overall, THIS GAME IS A MUST BUY, great game, if this was a finished game I would be happy with the purchase, but it's still only in beta!! I can't wait for further updates, and I wish all the luck in the world to the developers.

Early Access Review

Highly recommended. Maybe the best racing game on Linux. If you ever wanted to race with a futuristic car in a very futuristic world, this game is for you! Its racing with a twist, your car can perform various new functions such as jumping, wallriding and even flying! All this makes for very interesting race courses where the quickest way sometimes requires a lot of creativity. Something like extreme-G mixed with Trackmania.

Graphics and sound are excellent, but my favourite part is the gameplay. The car really controls so well, it is even possible to play with the keyboard. Good control is important as the game requires lighting fast reactions.

Note there are no AI oponents, hopefully this is something that will be added later. I had a lot of fun playing with random people through multiplayer though. The split screen option is also a very welcome addition and this can very easily be a fun game to play when having friends over. Just make sure to find an easy level pack first as most of the default levels take a lot of practice to master.
